or |blank1_data= --> | blank2_label = <!-- or |blank2_data= --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }} The '''2008 Zimbabwean cholera outbreak''' was an epidemic of [[cholera]] affecting much of Zimbabwe from August 2008 until June 2009. The outbreak began in [[Chitungwiza]] in [[Mashonaland East Province]] in August 2008, then spread throughout the country so that by December 2008, cases were being reported in all 10 [[Zimbabwe#Administrative divisions|provinces]].<ref name=ICDDRB>{{cite journal|author1=Ahmed S |author2=Bardhan PK |author3=Mazumder RN |author4=Khan AI |author5=Islam MS |author6=Siddique AK |author7=Cravioto A |title=The 2008 Cholera Epidemic in Zimbabwe: Experience of the icddr,b Team in the Field |journal=Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition |date=October 2011 |volume=29 |issue=5 |pages=541–546 |pmc=3225117 |pmid=22106761}}</ref> In December 2008, The [[Government of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwean government]] declared the outbreak a [[national emergency]] and requested [[international aid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/HEALTH/12/04/zimbabwe.cholera.emergency/ |accessdate=26 May 2016 |title=Zimbabwe declares cholera national emergency |date=9 December 2008 |publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref> The outbreak peaked in January 2009 with 8,500 cases reported per week.<ref name=WHOZim/> Cholera cases from this outbreak were also reported in neighboring countries [[South Africa]], [[Malawi]], [[Botswana]], [[Mozambique]], and [[Zambia]].<ref name=WHOZim/> With the help of international agencies, the outbreak was controlled, and by July 2009, after no cases had been reported for several weeks, the [[Ministry of Health and Child Welfare (Zimbabwe)|Zimbabwe Ministry of Health and Child Welfare]] declared the outbreak over.<ref name=WHOZim/> In total, 98,596 cases of cholera and 4,369 deaths were reported, making this the largest outbreak of cholera ever recorded in Zimbabwe.<ref name=WHOZim>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/cholera/countries/ZimbabweCountryProfileOct2009.pdf |accessdate=26 May 2016 |title=Cholera Country Profile: Zimbabwe |date=31 October 2009 |publisher=World Health Organization - Global Task Force on Cholera Control}}</ref> The large scale and severity of the outbreak has been attributed to poor sanitation, limited access to healthcare, and insufficient healthcare infrastructure throughout Zimbabwe.<ref name=WHOZim/><ref name=MSF>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news-stories/special-report/beyond-cholera-zimbabwes-worsening-crisis |accessdate=26 May 2016 |title=Beyond Cholera: Zimbabwe's Worsening Crisis |publisher=[[Medecins Sans Frontieres]]}}</ref>
== Cause == [[File:Kuwadzana open drain.JPG|250px|thumb|left|An open drain in [[Kuwadzana]] township, [[Harare]] in 2004. By 2008 drains such as this were carrying sewage from burst sewage pipes and [[feces]] washed out of the neighbouring areas as the urban sanitation system collapsed. This contributed to the rapid spread of the cholera outbreak.]] The 2008 cholera outbreak was caused by widespread infection with the bacterium ''[[Vibrio cholerae]]'' which is spread through water contaminated with the feces of infected individuals. Cholera had been seen in Zimbabwe in the decade leading up to the 2008 outbreak.<ref name=WHOZim/> However, the severity of the 2008 has been attributed to a combination of societal factors including poor access to [[health care]] and poor [[Health system|health care infrastructure]], high [[HIV]] prevalence, [[political instability]], food shortages, high levels of [[displaced person|displaced people]], and lack of access to [[potable water|safe water]].<ref name=MSF/> In 2008, Zimbabwe was suffering from an [[Economy of Zimbabwe#2000.E2.80.932009|economic crisis]] and [[Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe|hyperinflation]] which led to shortages of food and other basic goods, disruption of public services, and a large number of refugees moving within the country and to neighboring countries.<ref name=MSF/><ref name=PHR>{{cite web|publisher=Physicians for Human Rights |title=Health in Ruins: A Man-Made Disaster in Zimbabwe |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/PHR_Reports/health-in-ruins-zim-full-2009.pdf |accessdate=28 February 2012 |date=January 2009}}</ref>
<!--Water and Sanitation--> One of the major contributing factors to the outbreak was the breakdown of the municipal [[water supply]], [[sanitation]], and [[Waste management|waste collection]] programs throughout the country, but especially in urban areas.<ref name=collapse/> With this, the onset of the rainy season led to cholera-contaminated [[faeces]] being washed into water sources, in particular public drains,<ref name=storm/><ref name=rain/> as well as providing readily available but contaminated water.<ref name=coping>{{cite news|url=http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/html/zimbabwe-feature-261108?opendocument|title=Zimbabwe: coping with the cholera outbreak|date=26 November 2008|publisher=|accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref> Due to a shortage of purification chemicals, such as chlorine, the capital city of [[Harare]] stopped receiving piped water on 1 December 2008.<ref name=mobilize>{{cite news|url=http://www.zwnews.net/issuefull.cfm?ArticleID=19803 |title=United Nations, Red Cross mobilize cholera relief for Zimbabwe |date=3 Dec 2008 |publisher=VOA news |accessdate=2008-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208024523/http://www.zwnews.net/issuefull.cfm?ArticleID=19803 |archivedate=8 December 2008 }}</ref> By that date, many suburbs had not had any water supply for much longer.<ref name=3000dead/> On 4 December 2008, the Zimbabwe deputy minister for water and infrastructural development stated that there were only sufficient treatment chemicals in stock nationally for 12 weeks supply.<ref name=appeal>{{cite news|url=http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL4384569.html|title=Zimbabwe appeals for donor help on cholera|date=4 December 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=4 December 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206151851/http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL4384569.html|archive-date=6 December 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The collapse of these systems was blamed on the then-current [[Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe|economic crisis]];<ref name="Capital lacks clean water, cholera kills hundreds in Zimbabwe"/><ref name=oxfam>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e8d897e4-c0db-11dd-b0a8-000077b07658.html|title=Cholera death rate multiplies in Zimbabwe's economic crisis|date=3 December 2008|publisher=Financial Times (UK)|accessdate=4 December 2008}}</ref> many households cannot afford fuel to boil water.<ref name=oxfam2/> According to [[Médecins Sans Frontières]], the spread of cholera from urban to rural areas from December 2008 onwards was due to infected city-dwellers visiting their families' rural homes for Christmas and the burial of infected city-dwellers in rural areas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cholera moves to rural Zimbabwe|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7844417.stm|date=22 January 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=22 January 2009}}</ref>
<!--Health System Collapse-->
The 2008 cholera epidemic in Zimbabwe had an unusually high fatality rate; Oxfam attributed the high mortality to a population "seriously weakened by hunger, HIV and AIDS".<ref name=oxfam2/> A major contributing factor to the severity of the outbreak was the collapse of Zimbabwe's public health system, declared a national emergency on 4 December 2008.<ref name=emergency>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hsW9YNn1roEp0rzjeGSJo0pKcj2A|title=Zimbabwe declares cholera outbreak a national emergency|date=4 December 2008|publisher=AFP|accessdate=4 December 2008}}</ref> By the end of November 2008, three of Zimbabwe's four major hospitals had shut down, along with the Zimbabwe Medical School, and the fourth major hospital had two wards and no operating theatres working.<ref name=hospitals>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7714892.stm|title=The death throes of Harare's hospitals|date=7 November 2008|publisher=BBC |accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref><ref name=hospitals2>{{cite news|url=http://www.radiovop.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4452&Itemid=755|title=Zimbabwe's Medical School Closes|date=19 November 2008|publisher=Radio VOP|accessdate=3 December 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206141027/http://www.radiovop.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4452&Itemid=755|archive-date=6 December 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Zimbabwean hospitals still open by December 2008 lacked medicines and staff. Due to [[Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe|hyperinflation]], hospitals were not able to buy basic drugs and medicines, and the resources of even internationally funded emergency clinics were stretched.<ref name=coping/> The ongoing political and economic crisis contributed to the emigration of doctors and people with medical knowledge.<ref name="Zimbabwe cholera deaths near 500 ">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7760088.stm|title=Zimbabwe cholera deaths near 500 |date=2 December 2008|publisher=BBC |accessdate=2 December 2008}}</ref> Some victims were travelling to [[Botswana]] and other neighbouring countries for treatment.<ref name="Capital lacks clean water, cholera kills hundreds in Zimbabwe">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/12/01/zimbabwe.cholera/index.html?eref=rss_world|title=Capital lacks clean water, cholera kills hundreds in Zimbabwe|date=1 December 2008|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2 December 2008}}</ref>
== Impact == [[File:Zimcholeracases2.png|350px|thumb|right|The spread of cholera in Zimbabwe: (top) The number of cases recorded in the most infected centres and districts, and in the remainder of each province of Zimbabwe as of 4 March 2009. (bottom) Total number of reported cases. Since totals for many districts are not updated daily, the first occurrence of a case may represent the date of the reporting of that case, not the date of infection. Data sources: [[United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]],<ref name=daily>{{cite web|last=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|first=|authorlink=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|title =Daily Cholera Update|work=|publisher=|date=24 November 2008|url=http://ochaonline.un.org/CholeraSituation/tabid/5147/language/en-US/Default.aspx|format=|doi=|accessdate=27 January 2009}}</ref> the [[World Health Organization]],<ref name=epidemiologicaljan03>{{cite web|last=World Health Organization|first=|authorlink=World Health Organization|title=WHO Zimbabwe Cholera Epidemiological Bulletin No. 4, 3 January 2009|work=|publisher=|date=3 January 2009|url=http://ochaonline.un.org/OchaLinkClick.aspx?link=ocha&docId=1099223|format=|doi=|accessdate=15 January 2009}}</ref> the [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]].<ref name=ifrcrc/><ref>''[http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/retrieveattachments?openagent&shortid=CJAL-7LAP6F&file=Full_Report.pdf Zimbabwe: Cholera Outbreak]''. [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]], 11 November 2008</ref> and news media,<ref name=collapse>{{cite news|url=http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/region/africa/081203-zimbabwe-cholera|title=Zimbabwe in collapse|date=3 December 2008|publisher=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|accessdate=3 December 2008|archive-url=https://archive.is/20081205182708/http://www.radionetherlands.nl/currentaffairs/region/africa/081203-zimbabwe-cholera|archive-date=5 December 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=mobilise>{{cite news|url=http://www.zwnews.net/issuefull.cfm?ArticleID=19803 |title=United Nations, Red Cross mobilize cholera relief for Zimbabwe |date=3 December 2008 |publisher=VOA news |accessdate=3 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208024523/http://www.zwnews.net/issuefull.cfm?ArticleID=19803 |archivedate=8 December 2008 }}</ref><ref name=standard>{{cite news|url=http://www.thezimbabwestandard.com/local/19302--doctors-saycholera-toll-now-800.html |title=Doctors Say Cholera Toll Now 800 |date=29 November 2008 |publisher=The Standard (Zimbabwe) |accessdate=10 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090103004902/http://www.thezimbabwestandard.com/local/19302--doctors-saycholera-toll-now-800.html |archivedate=3 January 2009 }}</ref><ref name=newzimbabwe/><ref>''[http://ochaonline.un.org/OchaLinkClick.aspx?link=ocha&docId=1095879 Zimbabwe Humanitarian Situation Report On Cholera Outbreak]'', United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, 12 September 2008.</ref><ref name=redalert>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23598833-details/Red+alert+as+cholera+crisis+spreads+to+Zimbabwe's+neighbours/article.do|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130114035712/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23598833-details/Red+alert+as+cholera+crisis+spreads+to+Zimbabwe's+neighbours/article.do|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 January 2013|title=Red alert as cholera crisis spreads to Zimbabwe's neighbours|date=9 December 2009|publisher=Evening Standard (UK)|accessdate=9 December 2008}}</ref>]]
The 2008 outbreak began in [[Chitungwiza]] on 20 August 2008.<ref name=WHOEpi1>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/hac/crises/zwe/zimbabwe_cholera_epi_bulletin1_15dec2008.pdf |accessdate=23 July 2016 |title=Cholera in Zimbabwe:Epidemiological Bulletin number 1 |date=15 December 2008 |publisher=World Health Organization}}</ref> In September, cases spread to the urban areas of [[Makonde (District)|Makonde]] and [[Chinhoyi]].<ref name=WHOEpi1/> By the end of October, cases had spread to 3 provinces: [[Mashonaland West]], [[Mashonaland East]], and [[Harare|Harare city]]. In the first two weeks of November, the epidemic rapidly spread across Zimbabwe, appearing in a total of 9 provinces and 54 districts.<ref name=WHOEpi1/> The disease spread to reach all of [[Provinces of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe's ten provinces]].<ref name=daily/><ref name=storm>{{cite news|url= http://www.irinnews.org/Report.aspx?ReportId=81699|title=ZIMBABWE: Cholera feeds off a perfect storm|date=27 November 2008<!-- 2008-->| publisher=IRIN|accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref> The attack rate was highest in Beitbridge, Chegutu, Mudzi and Zvimba Districts (above 1,000 cases per 100,000 people or 1.0%).<ref name=epidemiologicaljan03/>
The number of cases reported by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs escalated from 30 on 1 September 2008<ref name=sanitation>{{cite news|url=http://sanitationupdates.wordpress.com/2008/09/08/zimbabwe-harare-residents-slam-zinwa-after-fatal-cholera-outbreak/|title=Zimbabwe, Harare: Residents Slam ZINWA After Fatal Cholera Outbreak|date=8 September 2008 | publisher=Sanitation Updates|accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref> to 15,572 by 10 December.<ref name=newzimbabwe>{{cite news|url= http://www.newzimbabwe.com/pages/health12.19130.html|title=Cholera death toll tops 746|date=10 December 2008|publisher=New Zimbabwe.com| accessdate=3 December 2008}}</ref> According to the Red Cross, around 46% of reported deaths occur en route to clinics and hospitals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.zimbabwejournalists.com/story.php?art_id=5171&cat=1|title=Zimbabwe rainy season increasing cholera risk says British Red Cross|date=14 January 2009|publisher=Zimbabwe Journalists|accessdate=15 January 2009}}</ref> The head of the British [[Department for International Development]] in Harare said that "there are probably twice as many people with cholera as turn up for treatment".<ref name=overwhelmed>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article5315386.ece|title=Health clinics overwhelmed by cholera cases in Zimbabwe|date=10 December 2008|publisher= The Times (UK)|accessdate=10 December 2008 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Fletcher}}</ref>
The case fatality rate for the outbreak was higher than expected for such outbreaks, although it began declining by January 2009.<ref name=epidemiologicaljan03/> Official estimates of fatalities have run from 484 to 800, since the outbreak in August 2008,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/32e1d0aa-c076-11dd-9559-000077b07658.html|title=Cholera outbreak kills 484 in Zimbabwe|date=2 December 2008|publisher=Financial Times (UL)|accessdate=2 December 2008}}</ref> with an upper estimate of 3,000 from an anonymous senior official in the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare.<ref name=3000dead>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/3000-dead-from-cholera-in-zimbabwe-1035149.html|title=3,000 dead from cholera in Zimbabwe|date=26 November 2008|publisher=The Independent (UK)|accessdate=3 December 2008 | location=London | first=Basildon | last=Peta}}</ref> Fatality rates varied from 2.5% in Harare to 18% in Chitungwiza.<ref name=bulletin12dec/> In [[Harare]], the crisis reached the extent that the city council offered free graves to cholera victims.<ref name=rain>{{cite news|url=http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnJOE4AT06A.html |title=Zimbabwe says cholera epidemic may spread with rain |date=30 November 2008 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=3 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206151846/http://africa.reuters.com/top/news/usnJOE4AT06A.html |archivedate=6 December 2008 |df= }}</ref> By 7 December, [[Oxfam]] estimated 60,000 cases by the end of January 2009 and a 10% fatality rate,<ref name=oxfam2>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/zimbabwe/3660739/Zimbabwes-cholera-victims-ten-times-more-likely-to-die.html|title=Zimbabwe's cholera victims 'ten times more likely to die'|date=7 December 2008|publisher=Telegraph (UK)|accessdate=8 December 2008 | location=London | first1=Sebastien | last1=Berger | first2=Peta | last2=Thornycroft}}</ref> with [[UNICEF]] giving a similar estimate.<ref name=cholerajump>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7769642.stm|title=Zimbabwe 'set for cholera jump'|date=6 December 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=6 December 2008}}</ref> On 4 December 2008, the [[government of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe government]] declared the outbreak to be a national emergency.<ref name=emergency/>
== Response ==
Assistance after the 2008 outbreak was made available by numerous international agencies,<ref name=coping/> and funding for water, sanitation and hygiene programmes, epidemic response and the provision of essential drugs came from several governments and trans-governmental organisations:

news|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/releases/archive/January2009/13/c7014.html|title=World Vision, HIPC airlifts $4 million cholera medications to Zimbabwe|date=13 January 2009|publisher=Newswire (Canada)|accessdate=15 January 2009}}</ref> |}
By 7 December 2008, [[UNICEF]] had secured international donor funding to provide sufficient water treatment chemicals for three weeks water supply for Harare and had arranged a shipment of chemical sufficient for four months supply.<ref name=oxfam2/> UNICEF distributed 360,000 litres of water per day in Harare, as well as handing out soap and buckets.<ref name=overwhelmed/> Notwithstanding the contributions received, UNICEF indicated on 9 December 2008 that US$17,500,000 was needed to respond properly to the outbreak.<ref name=descent>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/MCOI-7M8MGB?OpenDocument&rc=1&emid=ACOS-635PHU|title=Zimbabwe: Tracking the Descent|date=11 December 2008|publisher=ReliefWeb|accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref> As of 15 December, following agreement with the Zimbabwe government, the [[World Health Organization]] was procuring medical supplies to roll out a response plan to run health centres.<ref name=tollup>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/MYAI-7MD5EL?OpenDocument&rc=1&emid=ACOS-635PHU|title=Zimbabwe cholera death toll nears 1,000, UN reports|date=15 December 2008|publisher=United Nations News Service|accessdate=16 December 2008}}</ref>
==Spread == [[File:Spread of Zimbabwean Cholera Outbreak.svg|350px|thumb|right|Spread of cholera within southern Africa, as of 10 February 2009. Not all cases are part of the 2008–2009 Zimbabwean cholera outbreak. <br>'''Key:'''<br><span style="color:red;">█</span> Deaths recorded<br> <span style="color:orange;">█</span> Infections recorded]] The 2008 cholera outbreak spread to districts in [[Botswana]], [[Mozambique]], South Africa and [[Zambia]] bordering Zimbabwe.<ref name=WHOZim/>
===South Africa=== Cholera spread to the Zimbabwean migrant worker community in [[Limpopo]] and [[Mpumalanga]] provinces of South Africa<ref name=crosses>{{cite news|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/4d2d97e46fa9854480cd3d665a8a49bf.htm|title=SOUTH AFRICA-ZIMBABWE: Cholera crosses the border too|date=19 November 2008|publisher= IRIN via Reuters|accessdate=19 November 2008}}</ref> and cholera bacteria were detected in the [[Limpopo River]] on 3 December 2008.<ref name=descent/> By 12 December 2008, 11 deaths and 859 infections had been recorded in South Africa,<ref name=bulletin12dec>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/EGUA-7MCQLR?OpenDocument&rc=1&emid=ACOS-635PHU|title=Zimbabwe health cluster weekly bulletin No. 2 – 12 Dec 2008|date=12 December 2008|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=16 December 2008}}</ref> rising to 2,100 cases and 15 deaths by 14 January 2009,<ref name=neighboursrise>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5inUrjOec8guxoAGDFfCrqaftxyMQ|title=Zimbabwe cholera surges as neighbours report rising cases|date=15 January 2009|publisher=AFP|accessdate=15 January 2009}}</ref> and to 12,000 cases and 59 deaths by 10 March.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gLRGT2fcbFvRKCiIagnxkaRGodHA AFP S.Africa cholera outbreak 'declining']</ref>
The [[South African government]] set up medical facilities and drinking water supplies at the [[Beitbridge]] border post<ref name=border>{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=vn20081204051853844C776011|title=SA–Zim border under close watch |date=4 December 2008|publisher=Independent Online (South Africa)| accessdate=4 December 2008}}</ref> and deployed the National Outbreak Response Team and additional medical personnel to [[Musina]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Statement by Minister of Health Barbara Hogan on the outbreak of cholera in Zimbabwe and South Africa|url=http://www.info.gov.za/speeches/2008/08112711451003.htm|date=26 November 2008|publisher=SA Government Information Service|accessdate=22 January 2009}}</ref> Anthony Turton, a [[political scientist]] and Unit Fellow with the [[Council for Scientific and Industrial Research]] (CSIR) in South Africa, who had earlier warned of the risk of cholera in South Africa and wrote a report that recommended that the South African government increase its spending on water treatments lest a cholera outbreak occur in the country,<ref name="environment.co.za">http://www.environment.co.za/documents/water/KeynoteAddressCSIR2008.pdf</ref> was suspended for having made "inappropriate statements to the media".<ref name=turton>{{cite news| url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7752682.stm|title=South Africa at risk of cholera|date=27 November 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate= 9 December 2008}}</ref> On 10 December 2008, the Limpopo Provincial Government declared [[Vhembe District Municipality]], which borders Zimbabwe at Beitbridge, [[Matabeleland South]] province, a disaster area.<ref name=nocholera/> On a 28 January 2009 visit to [[Musina]] with high-ranking [[Government of South Africa|government]] and [[African National Congress|ruling party]] officials, [[South African Health Ministry|Health Minister]] [[Barbara Hogan]] said {{quote|Cholera is spreading... We are beginning to see a shift from Zimbabwe to South Africa. The situation is scary... I am concerned about the impact this is having on our provinces.<ref name=scary>{{cite news|title=Cholera situation is 'scary', says Hogan|date=28 Jan 2009|publisher=The Times (South Africa)|url=http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=926867|accessdate=29 January 2009}}</ref> }}
===Other countries=== The spread of cholera to Zimbabwe's other neighbouring countries was initially slower than in South Africa, with one death recorded in [[Districts of Zambia#Lusaka Province|Kafue District]] in Zambia and none in Botswana or [[Namibia]] by 9 December 2008.<ref name= redalert/> In 2009, cases increased, with 4,354 cases and 55 deaths reported by 10 February 2009 in Zambia and 1,596 cases and 14 deaths in [[Katanga Province|Katanga]], the southernmost province of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|DR Congo]].<ref name=rel>{{cite web|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/EGUA-7PKQ35?OpenDocument|title=Africa weekly emergency situation update Vol. 2, No. 8|author=[[World Health Organization]]|publisher=ReliefWeb|accessdate=28 February 2009}}</ref> In Mozambique, cholera spread to 10 out of 11 provinces,<ref name=rel/> with a total of 9,533 cases by 1 Jan to 1 Mar 2009 and 119 deaths by 17 March.<ref name="afp119">[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iUhFqAALo1-pIJv3OKCajIZW0Jsw AFP:12 Mozambican prisoners die after cholera riot]</ref> Four health workers also died in a mob attack, blamed on "misinformation and misunderstanding in efforts to combat cholera",<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.apanews.net/apa.php?page=show_article_eng&id_article=90608|publisher=APAnews|title=Mob kills health workers in Mozambique over cholera deaths|date=3 March 2009|accessdate=3 March 2009}}</ref> and 12 of the prisoners from the incident died in jail.<ref name="afp119"/> In Malawi 104 deaths were recorded since January, making it the worst outbreak since 2001–02 where 960 people died.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE52J0KJ20090320|publisher=Reuters|title=Malawi: Malawi says cholera outbreak kills 104|date=20 March 2009|accessdate=22 March 2009}}</ref> Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania, DRC, and Ghana have had unrelated cholera outbreaks with between 10–100 deaths in 2009 as of February.<ref name=rel/>
==Prevention== After the 2008 epidemic was declared a national emergency, the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare (MOHCW) collaborated with several other departments, governments, and non-governmental organizations to create a Cholera Command and Control Centre. This Centre works to prevent cholera outbreaks in Zimbabwe by addressing broader societal factors that could contribute to cholera outbreaks, such as water sanitation and poor hygiene habits.<ref name=socialdeterminants />
== Politicisation == Because of its well-organised health care system and effective water sanitation facilities, [[Rita R. Colwell]] of the [[James Baker Institute]] says Zimbabwe was historically one of the African countries least affected by cholera.<ref name ="bakerinstitute"/> A news commentary in ''[[The Lancet]]'' said that, under President [[Robert Mugabe]], the country's health programs were negatively impacted, resulting in diminished health care for those infected with cholera.<ref name=thelancet /> According to a draft paper from the WHO's World Conference on Social Determinants in Health, there were fewer health workers in the villages than in urban areas, which hindered early detection and isolation of cholera cases.<ref name=socialdeterminants>{{cite web|title=Intersectoral Actions in response to cholera in Zimbabwe: From emergency response to institution building|url=http://www.who.int/sdhconference/resources/draft_background_paper23_zimbabwe.pdf |format=PDF|work=World Conference on Social Determinants of Health |publisher= World Health Organization |accessdate=30 November 2013 |date= 19–21 October 2011}}</ref>
A news commentator writing for ''The Lancet'', Andrew Meldrum, said that President Mugabe’s Youth Militia threatened health professionals that provided medical treatment to political opponents.<ref name="thelancet">{{cite journal |author=Meldrum A |title=Zimbabwe's health-care system struggles on |journal=Lancet |volume=371 |issue=9618 |pages=1059–60 |date=March 2008 |pmid=18380032 |url= http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(08)60468-7/fulltext. |doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(08)60468-7}}</ref> He said that, combined with decreasing education standards, low pay, and a shortage of medical supplies like latex gloves, this led doctors to leave Zimbabwe at an alarming rate.<ref name="thelancet" /> According to Douglas Gwatidzo, the chairman of the Zimbabwe Doctors for Human Rights group, Zimbabwe had only one doctor assigned to a group of 12,000 citizens.<ref name="thelancet" /> Doctors in Zimbabwe fill only 25% of the medical posts available, and even fewer specialist positions are taken.<ref name="thelancet" /> According to Meldrum, this poses serious challenges to health care for diseases like HIV/AIDS and cholera. Similarly, the effects of cholera are exacerbated without proper nutrition, and Zimbabwe has faced food shortages for the last several years.<ref name="thelancet" />
Cholera and malnutrition keep children out of school – a serious social consequence of the outbreak. Rachel Pound, the director of [[Save the Children]] in Zimbabwe, said that attending school may be dangerous in Zimbabwe, instead of providing a ladder for self-improvement. She noted that "Sanitation is now so bad in schools that they may become a breeding ground for infection", rather than a place of valuable education.<ref name="thelancet_a">{{cite journal |author=Kapp C |title=Zimbabwe's humanitarian crisis worsens |journal=Lancet |volume=373 |issue=9662 |pages=447 |date=February 2009 |pmid=19205080 |url= http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(09)60151-3/fulltext |doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(09)60151-3}}</ref>
According to Meldrum, Zimbabwe's high inflation left the country with a lack of financial resources, resulting in a shortage of ambulances and pharmaceutical drugs.<ref name="thelancet" /> According to Eric Pruyt of the Delft University of Technology in The Netherlands, this was exacerbated by a shortage of international aid, as Zimbabwe's government didn't acknowledge the epidemic and accept aid until the disease was widespread.<ref name="scholar.google">{{cite journal |author= Pruyt, Eric |title= Cholera in Zimbabwe |url= http://www.systemdynamics.org/conferences/2009/proceed/papers/P1357.pdf |format= PDF |date= 26 July 2009 |publisher= Delft University of Technology |journal= |access-date= 30 November 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20131020151002/http://www.systemdynamics.org/conferences/2009/proceed/papers/P1357.pdf |archive-date= 20 October 2013 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> It was not contained or prevented from spreading. Until 2008, the government insisted that there was no cholera in Zimbabwe,<ref name=scholar.google /> and Pruyt says the U.N. did not provide the country with safe drinking water until after the crisis started.<ref name=scholar.google /> Meldrum says that, during Zimbabwe's continuing HIV/AIDS dilemma, some major international donors did not give much money because they believed it would help President Mugabe stay in power, which they did not want.<ref name="thelancet" />
As the outbreak and health crisis grew worse, American and British leaders cited the crisis as further proof that it was, in their view, "well past time for (President) [[Robert Mugabe]] to leave"<ref name=crash>{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=vn20081207085716656C601892|title=Zimbabwe crashes|date=7 December 2008|publisher=Independent Online (South Africa)|accessdate=7 December 2008}}</ref> and that Zimbabwe had become a [[failed state]].<ref name=closeborder>{{cite news|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/N11402094.htm|title=Zimbabwe neighbors should seal borders-US official|date=11 December 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref> Marian Tupy of the [[Cato Institute]] said that the crisis began in 2005 when the government took over water treatment facilities but without sufficient funding to maintain purification processes.<ref>{{cite web |author= Tupy, Marian |title= Mugabe's U.N. Helpers |url= http://www.cato.org/publications/commentary/mugabes-un-helpers?print |publisher= Cato Institute |date= 22 February 2010 |accessdate= 30 November 2013}}</ref> The transfer of water treatment from local government to the [[Zimbabwe National Water Authority]] was criticized by Innocent Nhapi of the National University of Rwanda on the basis of capacity and funding of the authority.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.2166/wp.2009.018|title=The water situation in Harare, Zimbabwe: A policy and management problem|year=2009|last1=Nhapi|first1=Innocent|journal=Water Policy|volume=11|issue=2|pages=221}}</ref> The lack of funding for water treatment chemicals, maintenance and staff salaries was cited by Colwell of the Baker Institute as a major cause of the epidemic.<ref name="bakerinstitute">{{cite AV media | people = [[Rita Colwell]] | title =Oceans, Climate, and Health: Cholera as a Model of Infectious Diseases in a Changing Environment | url =http://bakerinstitute.org/videos/civic-scientist-lecture-series-rita-colwell-oceans-climate-and-health-cholera-model-infectious-diseases-changing-environment/ | accessdate =2013-10-23 | publisher =James A Baker III Institute for Public Policy | location =Rice University }}</ref> According to Colwell, before funds were diverted from the plants to other uses, there were only sixty-five cases and four deaths from cholera in Zimbabwe.<ref name="bakerinstitute" />
According to an editorial by Daniel J Ncayiyana in the ''South African Medical Journal'', President Mugabe blamed the U.S. and the U.K. for the cholera outbreak, saying that they sent the disease so that they have a reason to credibly remove him from the presidency.<ref name="scielo">{{cite journal |author=Ncayiyana DJ |title=The Zimbabwe mayhem--how many people must die for the neighbours to act? |journal=S. Afr. Med. J. |volume=99 |issue=1 |pages=7 |date=January 2009 |pmid=19374075 |url= http://www.scielo.org.za/scielo.php?pid=S0256-95742009000100001&script=sci_arttext&tlng=pt }}</ref> One Zimbabwean citizen was shown with a sign that blamed UK Prime Minister Gordan Brown for the disease; the sign expressed the horrors of "Brown’s cholera".<ref name="scielo" />
According to a news report in ''[[Al Jazeera]]'', the [[Government of Zimbabwe|Zimbabwe government]] and state media blamed the outbreak on European and American sanctions<ref name=resign>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2008/12/2008127103521496227.html|title=Calls mount for Mugabe to resign |date=7 December 2008|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=7 December 2008}}</ref> and a Reuters report said it accused Britain of plotting an invasion under the cover of the outbreak.<ref name=invade>{{cite news|url=http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL7455762.html|title=Britain plots Zimbabwe invasion – Mugabe spokesman|date=7 December 2008|publisher=Reuters|accessdate= 7 December 2008}}</ref> Information minister [[Sikhanyiso Ndlovu]] blamed the cholera deaths on Western sanctions, saying "the cholera issue has been used to drive a wedge among us".<ref name=beyondcontrol>{{cite news|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Zimbabwe-Cholera-Crisis-New-Evidence-Of-Disease-Sweeping-Across-Robert-Mugabes-Country/Article/200812215175175?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_8&lid=ARTICLE_15175175_Zimbabwe_Cholera_Crisis%3A_New_Evidence_Of_Disease_Sweeping_Across_Robert_Mugabes_Country|title=Zim Cholera 'Is Beyond Control'|date=9 December 2008|publisher=Sky News (UK)|accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref> On 12 December, Ndlovu repeated his accusation, and claimed that the cholera outbreak was actually a "serious biological-chemical weapon" attack by the United Kingdom, which Ndlovu asserted was trying to commit [[genocide]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2008/12/20081212112525295564.html|title=Zimbabwe blames cholera on Britain|date=12 December 2008|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref> Said Ndlovu:
{{quote|Cholera is a calculated, racist, terrorist attack on Zimbabwe by the unrepentant former colonial power, which has enlisted support from its American and Western allies so that they can invade the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/africa/12/12/zimbabwe.mugabe/index.html|title=Zimbabwe: Cholera is genocide by UK|date=12 Dec 2008|publisher=CNN|accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7780728.stm|title=UK caused cholera, says Zimbabwe|date=12 December 2008|publisher=BBC|accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref>}}
In the meantime, a senior [[ZANU-PF]] official argued that the government and party leadership was more focussed on the forthcoming ZANU-PF conference than on the current crisis.<ref name=conference>{{cite news|url=http://www.iwpr.net/?p=zim&s=f&o=348282&apc_state=henh|title=Mugabe Allies Squash Succession Rumours|date=4 December 2008|publisher=institute for war & peace reporting|accessdate=7 December 2008}}</ref> On 11 December 2008, President Robert Mugabe made a speech screened on national television in which he said:
{{quote|I am happy to say our doctors have been assisted by others and WHO (the World Health Organization)... so now that there is no cholera... Because of cholera, [[Gordon Brown|Mr Brown]] wants a military intervention... [[George W. Bush|Bush]] wants military intervention because of cholera... There is no cause for war any more. The cholera cause doesn't exist any more.<ref name=nocholera>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article5323595.ece|title=Mugabe: 'There is no cholera in Zimbabwe'|date=11 Dec 2008|publisher=The Times (UK)|accessdate=11 December 2008 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Fletcher}}</ref><ref name=over/>}}
Reports from the [[World Health Organization|WHO]] contradicted Mugabe's view and indicated a growing death toll. According to the WHO, as of 8 December nearly 800 people had died of cholera and more than 16,000 cases were being treated.<ref name =over>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7777178.stm|title=Zimbabwe cholera is over – Mugabe|date=11 December 2008| publisher=BBC|accessdate=11 December 2008}}</ref> Later that same day, Zimbabwean visas were denied to six French aid workers, including three crisis management specialists, two [[epidemiology|epidemiologists]] and a [[water treatment]] expert.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/PANA-7M8EML?OpenDocument&RSS20=02|title=France says Zimbabwe denies visas to aid workers|date=11 December 2008|publisher=Reuters via ReliefWeb|accessdate=11 December 2008}}</ref> Britain's Africa minister, [[Mark Malloch-Brown]], dismissed Mugabe's claim that the Zimbabwe cholera crisis is over, commenting as follows:
{{quote|I don't know what world he [Mugabe] is living in. There is a raging humanitarian crisis in Zimbabwe as well as an economic crisis and still there is no representative government able to lead the country out of this disaster.<ref name=yescholera>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/dec/11/zimbabwe-cholera-robert-mugabe|title=UK dismisses Mugabe's claim that Zimbabwe cholera crisis is over|date=11 Dec 2008|publisher=The Guardian (UK)|accessdate=12 December 2008 | location=London | first=Mark | last=Tran}}</ref>}}
The [[Cabinet of France|French]] foreign ministry and [[USAID]] also contradicted Mugabe's statements and called on him to allow aid to reach the people in need.<ref name=closeborder/><ref name=yescholera/>
== See also == * [[Health in Zimbabwe]] * [[Water supply and sanitation in Zimbabwe]] * [[Cholera outbreaks and pandemics]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

'''Abortion in El Salvador''' is [[Law|illegal]]. The law formerly permitted an [[abortion]] to be performed under some limited circumstances, but, in 1998, all exceptions were removed when a new [[abortion law]] went into effect.<ref name="unpd">United Nations Population Division. (2002). [https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion Abortion Policies: A Global Review]. Retrieved July 14, 2006.</ref>
==History of Salvadoran abortion law== [[El Salvador]]'s 1956 [[Penal Code]] contained no explicit exception to its prohibition of abortion, although, under accepted principles of [[criminal law]], one could be justified if necessary to preserve the life of the pregnant woman. In response to the fact that the practice of illegal abortion was common, and was a major contributor to the rate of [[maternal mortality]], the Salvadoran government chose to expand the cases in which abortion was permitted.<ref name="unpd" />
Under the new Penal Code of 1973, an abortion could be legally allowed under three major conditions: if the [[pregnancy|pregnant]] woman's life was endangered and abortion was the only means to preserve it, if her pregnancy had resulted from [[rape]] or [[statutory rape]], or if a serious [[congenital disorder]] was detected in the [[fetus]]. An abortion caused on part of the woman's negligence was exempted from prosecution, and the government also provided reduced penalties for a woman of good standing if she had consented to an illegal abortion, or [[self-induced abortion|self-induced]] one, in the interest of protecting her [[reputation]].<ref name="unpd" />
==Reform process and current law== Proposals to eliminate the exceptions to the general prohibition against abortion started to come before the country's [[Legislative Assembly of El Salvador|Legislative Assembly]] in 1992. One bill would have resulted in the investigation of medical clinics suspected of providing abortion; as a result of a 1993 study, overseen by a politician affiliated with the [[Christian Democratic Party (El Salvador)|Christian Democratic Party]], several health care workers were arrested. Another proposal in 1993, which was supported by the Archbishop of [[San Salvador]] and the Say Yes to Life Foundation (a [[pro-life]] group), would have made December 28, a traditional [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] feast day known as the [[Day of the Innocents#Feast days|Day of the Innocents]], the "Day of the Unborn".<ref name="cfrr">Center for Reproductive Rights. (2001). [http://www.crlp.org/pub_bo_perse.htmlPersecuted: Political Process and Abortion Legislation in El Salvador]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Retrieved March 3, 2007.</ref>
In 1997, the [[Nationalist Republican Alliance]] (ARENA) submitted a draft bill, designed to amend the Penal Code to withdraw all grounds under which abortion was then permitted. On April 25, 1997, the Legislative Assembly voted 61 out of 84 to approve this modification to the Code.<ref name="cfrr" />
On April 20, 1998, the new Penal Code was enacted, removing the exceptions that had been instituted in 1973, including the provision for the pregnant woman's life. Under this Code, a person who performs an abortion with the woman's consent, or a woman who self-induces or consents to someone else inducing her abortion, can be imprisoned for two to eight years. A person who performs an abortion to which the woman has not consented can be sentenced to four to ten years in jail; if the person is a physician, pharmacist, or other health care worker, he or she is instead subject to between six and 12 years.<ref name="unpd" />
El Salvador also amended its Constitution in January 1999 to recognize human life from the moment of [[fertilisation|conception]].<ref name="cfrr" />
==Objections to the law== The organizations [[Ipas (organization)|IPAS]], MADRE, and Women's Link Worldwide submitted a report to the [[United Nations Human Rights Committee]] in which they contended that the El Salvadoran law against abortion violates several treaties that El Salvador has ratified: the [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] (ICCPR); the [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]] (ICESCR); the [[International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination]] (CERD); the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] (CRC); and the [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women]] (CEDAW).<ref name="unreport1"> {{cite web | title = Report on violations of women's human rights due to the complete criminalization of abortion | publisher = OHCHR | authors = IPAS, MADRE, CWGDTEEA(ES), Women's Link Worldwide | date = October 2010 | url = http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrc/docs/ngos/JointSubmission_ElSalvador100.pdf | accessdate = 2012-12-14 |postscript = . }} </ref>
They point out that "The [[Constitution of El Salvador]] protects every person’s right to life, liberty, security of person, and social justice. Furthermore it establishes that all persons are equal before the law and there can be no restrictions based on race, gender or religion. El Salvador’s criminal anti-abortion legislation violates all of these constitutional and human rights established in the previously mentions international conventions."<ref name="unreport1"/>
==Continued practice of abortion in El Salvador== [[Unsafe abortion]] is a serious public health problem and the second direct cause of [[maternal mortality]] in El Salvador. In 1994, the third-most-prevalent cause of mortality among adolescent girls was pregnancy and postpartum complications. Some of the girls arrested for trying to have [[abortion]]s are as young as ten. It's a drain on resources in a country where health care expenditures in 1997 were $24 per person per year.<ref name=pers1> {{cite web | title = Persecuted: Political Process and Abortion Legislation in El Salvador: A Human Rights Analysis | publisher = Center for Reproductive Law and Policy |author1=Soledad Varela |author2=Luisa Cabal | year = 2000 | url = http://reproductiverights.org/sites/default/files/documents/persecuted1.pdf | accessdate = 2012-12-15 | pages = 25–26 |postscript = . }} </ref>
The criminalization of abortion has extremely serious consequences for women’s lives and health: abortions performed under dangerous conditions; high mortality and morbidity rates; and a lack of reliable studies that could help health services provide better care to their clients, including women who have had abortions in unsafe conditions. This situation is further exacerbated by the persecution of women by the Salvadoran justice and health systems.<ref name=pers1/> In some cases, therapeutic abortions are performed by physicians in medical settings, and justified as other procedures, e.g. a [[laparotomy]] (abdominal incision) rather than an abortion.<ref name="nyt"/>
===Miscarriages=== Many low-income women who have a miscarriage or a stillbirth are often prosecuted. Oftentimes they are reported by medical personnel to the police and subsequently arrested in the hospital. They are wrongly accused of abortion or homicide and sentenced up to 40 years in prison. Currently, there are 17 women in prison for pregnancy related complications that have not had due process while being prosecuted.<ref>[https://www.amnestyusa.org/sites/default/files/el_salvador_report_-_on_the_brink_of_death.pdf],</ref>
===Abortion methods in El Salvador=== Doctors in El Salvador report that women seeking abortions use a wide variety of methods: clothes hangers, metal rods, high doses of contraceptives, fertilizers, gastritis remedies, soapy water, and caustic fluids (such as battery acid). The most common methods are pills, such as [[Cytotec]] and [[potassium permanganate]] (inserted vaginally); catheters to inject soapy water or caustic liquids; rods of any type of material to penetrate the [[uterus]]; injections of unknown solutions; or a combination of abortion methods, such as pills, a [[catheter]], and an injection or pills and a metal rod.<ref name=pers2> {{cite web | title = Persecuted: Political Process and Abortion Legislation in El Salvador: A Human Rights Analysis | pages = 48–49 | publisher = Center for Reproductive Law and Policy |author1=Soledad Varela |author2=Luisa Cabal | year = 2000 | url = http://reproductiverights.org/sites/default/files/documents/persecuted1.pdf | accessdate = 2012-12-15 |postscript = . }} </ref>
Using pills, catheters, injections and rods can kill a woman or injure her permanently. In addition to having only dangerous methods at their disposal, the women being tried for abortion were forced to self-induce abortions in their homes, in unsanitary conditions or in clandestine clinics that could not guarantee adequate procedures. If complications arise due to the conditions in which the abortion was practiced, they are then at risk of being reported by hospital staff who treat the complications. All of this highlights the risk to life, health, security of person and liberty that terminating an unwanted pregnancy represents for young, low-income women in El Salvador.<ref name=pers2/>
===Prosecutions=== A report in 2001 revealed that, after the new Penal Code went into effect in 1998, 69 cases of illegal abortions had been prosecuted. In 23 of those cases, the [[women]] involved had been turned over to the authorities by health care workers when they arrived at the hospital seeking treatment after an unsafe abortion. Most abortions had been self-induced, through the use of [[clothes hanger]]s, or by the ingestion of harmful amounts of [[hormonal contraception]] pills, [[antacid]]s, or [[misoprostol]] pills.<ref>Center for Reproductive Rights. (November 30, 2001). "[http://www.crlp.org/pr_01_1130salvador.html Severe Abortion Law in El Salvador Persecutes Women] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129232432/http://www.crlp.org/pr_01_1130salvador.html |date=2006-11-29 }}." Retrieved March 3, 2007.</ref>
In an article published in the April 9, 2006, edition of the ''[[New York Times Magazine]]'', writer [[Jack Hitt]] explored the effect of 1998 Penal Code.<ref>Hitt, Jack. (April 9, 2006). "[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/09/magazine/09abortion.html?ex=1302235200&en=d855d80018cd6c56&ei=5088&partner=rssuserland Pro-Life Nation]." ''The New York Times Magazine.'' Retrieved March 3, 2007.</ref> The article was later discredited when it was revealed that a woman mentioned as having been sentenced to 30 years in prison for an abortion, Carmen Climaco, had been jailed for homicide of a full-term infant.<ref>Calame, Byron. (December 31, 2006). "[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/31/opinion/31pubed.html?pagewanted=1&ei=5088&en=0b969b7478a93f06&ex=1325221200&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss Truth, Justice, Abortion and the Times Magazine]." ''The New York Times Magazine.'' Retrieved November 4, 2008.</ref> In fact, Karina del Carmen Herrera Climaco had given birth at home and then began to bleed heavily. (The pregnancy was almost certainly unintentional, as it occurred after a tubal ligation.) Her mother called police to take her to hospital. While she was in hospital, police searched her home and found a lifeless infant. Medical examination failed to determine if the infant was born alive or dead, nor a cause of death. Nevertheless, a sentence of aggravated homicide was passed, separating her from her three children. Almost 8 years later, thanks to the efforts of a group of activists and national and international attorneys, Karina’s sentence was reviewed. It was annulled and she was released. She has not been compensated for her eight years of incarceration.<ref name="unreport1"/>
Another 30-year sentence was passed out for an apparent miscarriage, in August 2008, by the Tribunal of [[San Francisco Gotera, Morazán|San Francisco Gotera]] in the department of [[Morazán Department|Morazan]]. María Edis Hernández Méndez de Castro, 30, was a single mother with 4 children when she found out she was pregnant. Maria told her family that she was pregnant, even though she didn't know how far along the pregnancy was. During the pregnancy, Maria felt a pain and went to the bathroom in her home at which time she suffered labor complications and passed out. She regained consciousness in the [[National Hospital of San Francisco]]. The doctor that treated Maria reported her to the police on suspicion of having an abortion. She was convicted of aggravated homicide and sentenced to thirty years in prison. Two more cases of women sentenced to lengthy prison terms for what might have been abortions or miscarriages are detailed in the same report.<ref name="unreport1"/>
===Medical harm=== The lack of contraceptive information and the ban on abortion put women's lives at risk, particularly when they are young. One-third of the women giving birth are 19 or younger, and a handful are 10 – 14 years old.<ref name="unreport1"/>
==Case of "Beatriz"== In 2013, a case arose of a pregnant 22-year-old woman, identified as "Beatriz," who, due to [[lupus]] aggravated by loss of kidney function, was told by doctors that she would likely die if she gave birth and that the child, due to its [[anencephaly]], would likely have only a few hours of life. Her doctors requested permission from the government to perform an abortion because the fetus was nonviable and Beatriz was likely to die. When the case came before the Supreme Court, the court denied Beatriz's request.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57586726/pregnant-el-salvador-woman-denied-life-saving-abortion/ |publisher=CBS |title=Pregnant El Salvador woman denied life-saving abortion |date=May 29, 2013 |first=Jessica |last=Hartogs}}</ref>
She was given permission to have an early [[caesarean section]], the same procedure that would have been used had the court ruled in her favor. Legally, this was not an abortion because the fetus was incubated and given fluids. The child died five hours after the procedure.<ref name="nyt">{{Cite news |work=The New York Times |first=Karla |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/05/world/americas/woman-who-sought-abortion-in-el-salvador-delivers-baby.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |date=June 5, 2013 |last=Zabludovsky |title=A High-Risk Pregnancy Is Terminated. But Was It an Abortion?}}</ref> Beatriz was able to recover and leave the hospital.<ref>{{Cite news |date=June 12, 2013 |url=http://noticias.latam.msn.com/xl/latinoamerica/articulo_afp.aspx?cp-documentid=258380250 |title=Beatriz se recupera de la cesárea y sale del hospital en El Salvador |agency=AFP}}</ref> The case was identified by reproductive rights activists as evidence of a lack of progress towards the goals of the 1994 [[International Conference on Population and Development]], which affirmed reproductive rights as human rights and emphasized the importance of reducing maternal mortality.<ref>{{Cite news |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/poverty-matters/2013/jul/05/el-salvador-abortion-womens-rights |date=5 July 2013 |first=Luisa |last=Cabal |title=El Salvador abortion controversy shows lack of progress on Cairo agenda}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Abortion]] *[[:Category:Abortion by country|Abortion by country]] *[[Abortion in Chile]] *[[Abortion in Nicaragua]] *[[Abortion law]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *"[https://web.archive.org/web/20081031084217/http://www.plannedparenthood.org/issues-action/international/cautionary-tale-6473.htm El Salvador's Cautionary Tale]" by Rhonda Schlangen {{Abortion in North America}} {{Abortion}}
